C target can only be achieved
that achieving both stated goals is an immense and widely
underestimated challenge, the successful management of which requires far greater room for man
in monetary and fiscal terms than is reflected in the current European political discourse.
The ‘Just Transition’ concept has evolved over the years
It emphasizes the key principles of respect and d
groups, the creation of decent jobs, social protection, employment rights, fairness in energy access and
use, and social dialogue and democratic consultation with relevant stakeholders, whilst coping with the
g or the transition to green and clean economies. The concept has come under
increased scrutiny, with its protagonists emphasizing the need to focus on the equality of the transition
emphasis on justice is also gaining in momentum
growing recognition that the sustainability transition is about justice in the transition and not simply
(Newell and Mulvaney 2013; Swilling, M. Annecke 2010; Williams and Doyon 2020)
Scholars are increasingly of the view that a transition
old forms of injustice with new ones
he economic implications of the transition will be felt by developing countries with high degrees of
dependence on hydrocarbon products as a revenue stream, as they are exposed to reduced fiscal
incomes, given the low demand for oil and low oil prices and
the associated economic fallout of the
This link with stranded assets is important, but it may be overlooked, as countries whose
assets are becoming stranded may not have the relevant resources, knowledge, autonomy
fresh orientation or decide on the transition.

t are sovereign matters. State responsibilities over
natural resources concern both current and future generations

required to enable a just transition are predicated on good leadership and governance institutions that

on land for food and at
the same time support carbon storage. With land coming under increased pressure, land and forest
management are critical for carbon sequ
as well as other ecosystem benefits. Extractive
in regions where extraction takes place. In addition, extraction of strategic minerals such as
copper and lithium have been linked to violence
carbon neutrality by 2050, some of the other priorities of the transition,
change adaptation and its inherent vulnerabilities, might become muted, given the urgenc
at all costs. Consequently, the transition imperative reduces the scope for local priority
setting and ignores the additional risks faced by countries with the least capacity to adapt. Equally, the
